testInfo.title: Biochemical Outbreak Test
testInfo.description: Test your survival instincts in a world ravaged by deadly pathogens

questions.text: Emergency alerts warn of a chemical weapons attack in your area. What's your immediate response?

options.text: Seal all windows and doors, create a safe room with air filtration
Evacuate immediately to higher ground upwind from the attack
Help neighbors understand what's happening before protecting myself
Wait for official instructions on what to do

questions.text: You smell something like almonds mixed with bleach in the air. What does this tell you?

options.text: Possible cyanide or chlorine gas - get a wet cloth over nose immediately
Chemical attack confirmed - find higher ground and fresh air
Something's wrong but I don't know what - follow others who seem to know
Probably just industrial pollution - not immediately dangerous

questions.text: Your makeshift gas mask is failing and you're starting to feel dizzy. What's your priority?

options.text: Find better filtration materials or sealed environment immediately
Move to the highest location possible - chemicals sink
Find other survivors who might have better protection to share
Accept that I'm probably fucked and try to help others while I can

questions.text: You find a family trapped in a contaminated building. They're begging for help but going in could kill you.

options.text: Try to guide them to safety from outside - don't risk contamination
Go in with whatever protection I have - can't leave them to die
Find others to help with the rescue - strength in numbers
Keep moving - I can't save everyone and they might already be dead

questions.text: Chemical burns are appearing on exposed skin. You need medical attention but hospitals are overwhelmed.

options.text: Flush with clean water, find basic medical supplies, treat myself
Find someone with medical training among other survivors
Force my way into a medical facility - this is life or death
Push through the pain - there are others worse off than me

questions.text: You discover a sealed military vehicle with protective gear inside, but taking it might be considered looting.

options.text: Take what I need to survive - emergency overrides normal laws
Take only what I need and leave the rest for others
Look for the vehicle's crew first - maybe they need help
Don't touch it - could be booby-trapped or monitored

questions.text: Wind patterns are shifting and bringing the chemical cloud toward your shelter. What's your strategy?

options.text: Evacuate immediately perpendicular to wind direction
Seal the shelter better and wait for wind to change again
Move the group to underground areas like subway tunnels
Split up to increase chances someone survives

questions.text: You meet a scientist who claims to know how to neutralize the chemical threat, but they need dangerous materials.

options.text: Help them gather materials - this could save everyone
Verify their credentials and plan before committing
Too risky - focus on protecting my immediate group instead
Sounds like bullshit - probably trying to get us killed

questions.text: Food and water supplies are running low, but everything outside is potentially contaminated. What's your approach?

options.text: Carefully decontaminate found supplies using proper procedures
Risk short exposure trips to gather sealed/packaged items
Ration what we have and wait for external rescue
Eat whatever we can find - starvation is a guaranteed death

questions.text: A government vehicle offers evacuation, but you've heard rumors that evacuation centers are death traps.

options.text: Go with them - official help is better than staying here
Ask detailed questions about the destination before deciding
Politely decline and continue self-rescue efforts
Tell them to fuck off - government caused this mess

questions.text: You've been exposed to chemicals for days. Early symptoms include nausea and breathing problems. What's your response?

options.text: Start immediate decontamination and find medical treatment
Document symptoms and try to find others with medical knowledge
Push through it - showing weakness will panic the group
Isolate myself to avoid contaminating others further

questions.text: Your group finds a factory with intact air filtration systems, but it's in the middle of the contamination zone.

options.text: Plan a careful approach with maximum protection to secure it
Send a small scouting team first to verify it's safe
Too dangerous - find alternatives that don't require exposure
Go for it immediately before someone else claims it

questions.text: Chemical weapons have created different contamination zones. Which area do you prioritize avoiding?

options.text: Low-lying areas where heavier gases accumulate
Areas with visible chemical residue or dead vegetation
Anywhere with dead animals or people - clear danger signs
I don't know enough about chemicals to make informed choices

questions.text: You discover that the chemical attack was targeting water supplies. How do you handle hydration?

options.text: Only use sealed bottled water or water I can properly purify
Collect rainwater and test it before consumption
Boil all water sources thoroughly before drinking
Risk drinking local water - dehydration will kill me faster

questions.text: A child in your group is showing severe chemical poisoning symptoms. Medical help is days away.

options.text: Use whatever medical supplies I have and try basic treatment
Attempt to reach medical help faster, even if it's dangerous
Focus on keeping them comfortable and minimizing further exposure
Accept that some people can't be saved and protect the healthy ones

questions.text: You find a working radio broadcasting instructions for chemical decontamination. Do you trust the source?

options.text: Follow the instructions carefully - expert advice is valuable
Cross-reference with my own knowledge before implementing
Try the methods on non-critical items first to test effectiveness
Ignore it - radio broadcasts could be misinformation or traps

questions.text: Three weeks in, you realize the chemical contamination is permanent in some areas. What's your long-term strategy?

options.text: Establish a permanent base in clean areas with sustainable resources
Keep moving to stay ahead of contamination spread
Adapt to living with contamination using protective measures
Focus on finding other survivor communities to join forces

questions.text: You encounter a group that's become immune to the chemicals through gradual exposure. They offer to help you adapt.

options.text: Carefully study their methods and try gradual adaptation
Join them but maintain protective measures until proven safe
Too risky - controlled exposure could kill rather than immunize
They're probably already brain-damaged from exposure

questions.text: Your protective equipment is failing and replacement parts are impossible to find. What's your approach?

options.text: Improvise repairs and upgrades using available materials
Find other survivors who might have spare equipment to trade
Minimize exposure by staying in safe zones as much as possible
Accept increased exposure risk - can't hide forever

questions.text: Six months later, you've survived but many others haven't. How do you deal with survivor's guilt?

options.text: Focus on helping rebuild and honoring those who didn't make it
Use my survival skills to teach and protect other survivors
Compartmentalize the emotions and focus on practical survival
Struggle with it daily - survival feels meaningless without others

questions.text: You discover the chemical attack was a test run for something worse. How do you use this information?

options.text: Warn other survivor communities and help them prepare
Use the knowledge to better prepare my own group
Try to find and stop whoever is responsible
Keep it secret - this information could cause mass panic

questions.text: A year later, chemical-resistant crops are finally growing. How do you handle food production?

options.text: Establish secure farming communities with shared knowledge
Guard the farming secrets and control food distribution
Focus on preserving and storing as much as possible
Share freely to help rebuild civilization faster

questions.text: You've developed expertise in chemical decontamination. Other survivors come to you for help constantly.

options.text: Train others to spread the knowledge and reduce dependence on me
Help everyone but maintain my position as the expert
Charge resources for my services - expertise has value
Limit my help to avoid burnout and maintain my own safety

questions.text: Two years after the attack, you must choose between staying in the safe zone you've built or exploring the recovering world.

options.text: Stay and continue building a stable, sustainable community
Explore to gather intelligence and establish trade networks
Help other communities by sharing our successful model
Keep a low profile - success makes us a target

questions.text: Looking back on surviving the chemical apocalypse, what was your most important survival trait?

options.text: Technical knowledge about chemicals and decontamination
Ability to adapt quickly to constantly changing threats
Building and maintaining trust within survivor groups
Mental toughness to keep going when everything seemed hopeless

results.title: Chemical Warfare Expert
results.shortDescription: You've mastered the deadly art of surviving chemical warfare. Your knowledge of decontamination and chemical threats makes you invaluable in the toxic wasteland.
extendedDescription: When chemical weapons turned the air into poison, you didn't just survive - you became a master of the new toxic reality. Your deep understanding of chemical threats, decontamination procedures, and protective measures has made you the go-to expert that other survivors depend on for life-or-death decisions. You can read chemical danger signs like others read street signs.

Your survival strategy is built on scientific knowledge and methodical preparation. While others panicked or made fatal mistakes, you applied chemistry principles and proper protocols to navigate the chemical hellscape. Your ability to improvise decontamination equipment, identify different chemical threats, and establish safe procedures has saved countless lives.

What sets you apart is your combination of technical expertise and practical application. You don't just know the theory - you've proven these skills under the most extreme conditions possible. Your careful risk assessment and evidence-based decision making have earned you the trust and respect of survivor communities who know that following your advice means staying alive.

You've become more than just a survivor - you're a teacher and protector whose knowledge helps rebuild civilization in a chemically compromised world. Your expertise will be essential for generations as humanity learns to live with the long-term consequences of chemical warfare.

results.title: Decontamination Specialist
results.shortDescription: You've turned cleaning into a survival skill. Your mastery of decontamination procedures keeps you and your community safe from chemical threats.
extendedDescription: In a world where a single contaminated item can kill, you've become the master of making things safe again. Your expertise in decontamination procedures, from improvised field methods to complex multi-stage cleaning protocols, has become your most valuable survival skill. You understand that in chemical warfare, cleanliness literally means life or death.

Your approach to survival is methodical and thorough. You've learned to see contamination everywhere and developed systems to safely handle food, water, equipment, and even people who've been exposed to chemical agents. Your attention to detail and systematic thinking have prevented countless poisoning incidents in your community.

What makes you invaluable is your ability to teach others these critical skills while maintaining safety standards under pressure. You've created decontamination protocols that work with limited resources and trained other survivors to properly execute them. Your work allows communities to safely expand their operations into contaminated areas.

Your legacy will be the knowledge and procedures you've developed that allow human civilization to reclaim contaminated territories. Your systematic approach to decontamination has not only kept people alive but created the foundation for long-term recovery and reconstruction in a poisoned world.

results.title: Toxic Navigator
results.shortDescription: You've learned to read the poisoned landscape like a map. Your ability to navigate chemical hazards safely makes you the guide others trust with their lives.
extendedDescription: While others see only death and poison, you see patterns, safe routes, and survivable risks. Your ability to navigate through chemically contaminated terrain has made you an essential guide for any group that needs to move through the toxic wasteland. You've developed an almost supernatural sense for reading chemical danger signs and finding safe passage.

Your survival skills are built on observation, experience, and calculated risk-taking. You understand how chemicals behave in different weather conditions, how they accumulate in terrain features, and how to minimize exposure while still accomplishing necessary missions. Your route-finding abilities have saved lives and opened up resources that others couldn't safely access.

What sets you apart is your combination of environmental awareness and tactical thinking. You don't just avoid danger - you find ways to use environmental knowledge to your advantage, whether that's timing movements with wind patterns or identifying overlooked safe zones. Your expertise allows groups to operate effectively in areas others consider completely uninhabitable.

Your knowledge of the toxic landscape makes you invaluable for both immediate survival and long-term planning. As communities work to reclaim contaminated areas, your understanding of chemical distribution patterns and safe navigation techniques will be crucial for expansion and resource recovery efforts.

results.title: Community Protector
results.shortDescription: You've dedicated yourself to keeping others safe from chemical threats. Your protective instincts and group management skills build strong, resilient communities.
extendedDescription: When the chemical weapons fell, your first instinct wasn't just self-preservation - it was protecting others. Your natural leadership abilities and strong protective instincts have made you the backbone of survivor communities, organizing group safety protocols and ensuring that everyone has the knowledge and equipment they need to survive chemical threats.

Your strength lies in thinking beyond individual survival to community resilience. You've organized supply chains for protective equipment, established training programs for chemical safety, and created support systems for people dealing with exposure or trauma. Your ability to maintain group cohesion under extreme stress has kept communities together when fear and desperation could have torn them apart.

What makes you essential is your balance of practical protective measures with emotional support. You understand that surviving chemical warfare isn't just about avoiding poison - it's about maintaining hope, purpose, and human connections in an environment designed to break the human spirit. Your leadership provides both physical safety and psychological stability.

Your legacy will be the strong, resilient communities you've helped build that can not only survive chemical threats but thrive despite them. Your focus on collective security and mutual aid has created models for how human society can adapt to and overcome even the most devastating environmental challenges.

results.title: Chemical Survivor
results.shortDescription: You've survived exposure and lived to tell about it. Your hard-won experience with chemical effects makes you tough and knowledgeable about recovery.
extendedDescription: You didn't just avoid chemical exposure - you survived it. Your body bears the marks of chemical warfare, but your mind carries the invaluable knowledge of what it's really like to face these weapons and live through the experience. Your survival has given you insights that can't be learned from textbooks or secondhand accounts.

Your approach to survival is informed by harsh personal experience with chemical effects, treatment, and recovery. You understand the real timeline of chemical poisoning, what symptoms actually mean, and what treatments work under field conditions. Your knowledge has helped others recognize and respond to exposure before it becomes fatal.

What makes you unique is your combination of technical knowledge and lived experience. You can speak with authority about both the science of chemical weapons and the human reality of surviving them. Your credibility comes from your scars, and other survivors listen to you because they know you've been where they fear to go.

Your survival story provides hope to others who face exposure, and your practical knowledge of recovery and adaptation helps communities deal with long-term chemical effects. You've proven that chemical warfare isn't an automatic death sentence, and your example inspires others to keep fighting even after exposure.

results.title: Resource Manager
results.shortDescription: You've mastered the logistics of surviving in a chemically contaminated world. Your resource management skills keep communities supplied and functioning.
extendedDescription: Surviving chemical warfare isn't just about avoiding poison - it's about managing the complex logistics of life in a contaminated world. Your expertise in resource management, supply chain thinking, and strategic planning has made you the person communities rely on to keep everyone fed, equipped, and protected in impossible circumstances.

Your survival strategy focuses on systems and sustainability rather than day-to-day crisis management. You've developed protocols for safely acquiring, testing, and distributing resources in a contaminated environment. Your forward-thinking approach to stockpiling, trade networks, and resource allocation has prevented communities from falling into scarcity-driven conflicts.

What sets you apart is your ability to think strategically about long-term survival while managing immediate needs. You understand the economics of the post-chemical world, where clean water might be worth more than gold and functional protective equipment becomes a currency unto itself. Your trading skills and resource networks give your community significant advantages.

Your legacy will be the sustainable systems you've created that allow communities to not just survive chemical contamination but build stable, prosperous societies despite it. Your understanding of resource management in extreme conditions provides the foundation for rebuilding civilization in a chemically challenged world.

results.title: Adaptive Survivor
results.shortDescription: You've learned to roll with whatever the chemical wasteland throws at you. Your flexibility and quick thinking help you navigate constantly changing threats.
extendedDescription: If chemical warfare has taught you anything, it's that rigid plans get you killed. Your superpower is adapting to rapidly changing chemical threats, shifting contamination patterns, and evolving survival challenges. When other survivors are still following outdated protocols, you've already adapted to new realities and found innovative solutions.

Your approach to chemical survival is experimental and opportunistic. You're not locked into any single strategy - instead, you read chemical situations as they develop and adjust your tactics accordingly. This flexibility has allowed you to thrive in diverse contaminated environments and work effectively with different survivor groups using various approaches.

What makes you valuable is your ability to learn quickly from both successes and failures in chemical survival. You don't get stuck mourning the pre-chemical world or fixated on how decontamination 'should' work. Instead, you embrace the new toxic reality and find ways to turn chemical challenges into survival advantages.

Your adaptability ensures that you'll find ways to survive chemical scenarios that would doom more rigid thinkers. As chemical contamination patterns shift and new threats emerge, your flexible approach and innovative thinking will be essential for communities trying to navigate an ever-changing toxic landscape.

results.title: Toxic Nomad
results.shortDescription: You've learned that staying mobile is key to surviving chemical contamination. Your nomadic lifestyle keeps you ahead of toxic threats.
extendedDescription: While others tried to build permanent shelters and safe zones, you learned that mobility is the ultimate defense against chemical warfare. Your nomadic approach to survival, constantly moving ahead of contamination spreads and shifting threats, has kept you alive when static communities have been overwhelmed by toxic disasters.

Your survival strategy is built on speed, flexibility, and minimal dependencies. You've learned to travel light while carrying essential chemical protection, read environmental signs to predict contamination movement, and find temporary shelter in any environment. Your knowledge of routes, hideouts, and resource caches spans vast contaminated territories.

What keeps you alive is your ability to think like the chemicals themselves - always moving, following patterns, and adapting to environmental conditions. You understand that in chemical warfare, yesterday's safe zone is tomorrow's death trap, and your willingness to abandon comfortable situations has saved your life repeatedly.

Your nomadic lifestyle makes you valuable as a messenger, scout, and guide between isolated survivor communities. Your knowledge of contamination patterns across wide areas and your ability to safely traverse toxic terrain makes you an essential link in the network of human survival in the chemical wasteland.

results.title: Chemical Warrior
results.shortDescription: You've turned chemical survival into a combat skill. Your aggressive approach to handling toxic threats makes you a formidable force in the wasteland.
extendedDescription: You didn't just learn to survive chemical warfare - you learned to fight back against it. Your aggressive, combat-oriented approach to chemical threats has made you a formidable force in the toxic wasteland. You treat chemical contamination like an enemy to be defeated rather than a hazard to be avoided, and this mindset has made you incredibly effective.

Your survival strategy combines chemical knowledge with tactical thinking and aggressive problem-solving. You're willing to take calculated risks to neutralize chemical threats, rescue people from contaminated areas, or secure essential resources that others consider too dangerous to pursue. Your combat mindset gives you an edge in high-stakes chemical situations.

What makes you dangerous is your combination of chemical expertise with warrior mentality. You've weaponized your knowledge of decontamination and protection, using chemical principles tactically to outmaneuver both environmental threats and hostile survivors. Your approach inspires confidence in allies and fear in enemies.

Your warrior approach to chemical survival has made you a leader among the more aggressive survivor factions. Your willingness to take the fight to chemical threats rather than just enduring them has opened up possibilities that more defensive-minded survivors never considered, expanding the boundaries of what's possible in the toxic wasteland.

results.title: Contaminated Survivor
results.shortDescription: You've survived through grit and luck more than expertise. You're still breathing despite making some questionable choices in the chemical wasteland.
extendedDescription: You're living proof that sometimes survival is less about perfect chemical knowledge and more about sheer fucking determination to keep breathing toxic air. You might not have all the decontamination protocols memorized or the best protective equipment, but you have something equally valuable - an unbreakable will to live and an ability to stumble through chemical disasters without dying.

Your survival has been a combination of good instincts, decent luck, and a talent for learning from your chemical exposure mistakes without dying in the process. You've picked up decontamination skills through trial and error, formed alliances based on gut feelings rather than strategic planning, and somehow managed to avoid the worst chemical disasters through a mixture of caution and circumstance.

What keeps you alive is your authenticity and relatability to other survivors. You're not intimidating with perfect chemical expertise, which makes people more likely to help you or accept you into their groups. Your honest reactions to chemical threats remind others of their own humanity, and your determination to keep going despite contamination inspires hope.

Your proof that ordinary people can survive chemical warfare gives hope to everyone still fighting to stay alive in the toxic wasteland. While you may not be the most prepared or skilled chemical survivor, your persistence and refusal to give up demonstrates that chemical warfare isn't just survivable by experts - regular people can make it through too.
